Issues.Title: Unable to change all media queries values seamlessly
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma | the Docs**.


### Overview of the problem

Is there anyway to change all media queries for every class using one variable?

For example, any is-4, is-7 etc. classes on columns will always use a media min-width of 769px despite attempts to change the $tablet variable. 

Since $tablet has default value of $769px, which matches up with the media min-width values, it is assumed this is the var to change the min width values in the media queiries.

### Steps to Reproduce

Please use the following block of HTML as an example:

```
@media screen and (min-width: 769px), print
.columns:not(.is-desktop) {
    display: flex;
}
```

or 

```
@media screen and (min-width: 769px), print
.column.is-12, .column.is-12-tablet {
    flex: none;
    width: 100%;
}

```

is-6, is-4 etc. would have the same media queries where min-width is 769px

The docs say any modified variable e.g. $desktop or $tablet must be done BEFORE bulma is imported so in the scss file, we have this as well:

```
$tablet: 992px;
@import '~bulma/bulma.sass';

```

### Expected behavior

The media queries for .columns, .column, is-12 etc. should be applied to min-width: 992px;

### Actual behavior

The media query still gets applied to min-width: 769px.

Hence, changing the $tablet variable does not seem to work.

I thought that was the correct variable to modify since it's default value is $769px which matches up with what the media queries initially say.

perhaps it is not - if that is the case, how does one change the values in which media queries active for application of is-4-mobile, is-6, is-mobile etc?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unable to change all media queries values seamlessly" (#3043)

Issues.Title: Using the `is-<display>-<size>-only` helper does not work as expected
Issues.Body:
This is about **the Docs**. ### Overview of the problem This is about the Bulma **Docs** I'm using Bulma **version** [0.9.0] My **browser** is: Vivaldi 3.1.1929.45 / Firefox Developer Edition 79.0b1 I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate** ### Description Using the `is---only` helper does not work as expected when trying to make something show only at a particular size â€”Â setting something as `is-hidden is-block-tablet-only`, for example, causes it to be hidden at all sizes as `is-hidden` has `!important` on its `display: none`, and this always seems to override the `!important` on the `*-only` helpers. The only way I've found to make it work as expected is to define an extra class that just applies `display: none` without `!important`. I'm not sure whether this is the docs not being clear on how to use these, or an actual bug relating to all the `!important`s that Bulma uses; I've got the same results in Vivaldi and Firefox, so I'm assuming it's not a browser bug. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. View a page with the following source: ```html Demo
is-block-tablet-only
display: none
is-hidden before
is-hidden after
``` 2. Resize the page ### Expected behaviour When the page is in the tablet size range, all four divs display; they are hidden at other page sizes. ### Actual behaviour The `is-block-tablet-only` div is displayed at all sizes. The two `is-hidden` divs are not displayed at any sizes. Only the `display: none` div works as expected, but it needs the user to define a class that's not provided by Bulma.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Using the `is-<display>-<size>-only` helper does not work as expected" (#3041)

Issues.Title: Content class doesn't use $title-family sass variable
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** 9.0.0

### Description

When customizing bulma using `$title-family`, the font family is changed for `.title` class, but not for `.content > h*` headers.

### Steps to Reproduce

- Change $title-family
- Use any h tag within a tag with `.content`

### Expected behavior

The font family to change accordingly.

### Actual behavior

The font family is not changed.

### Notes

This may be intentional behavior, but then maybe a `$content-heading-family` variable should be added ?

I got around adding this for now : 
```scss
@for $i from 1 through 5 {
    h#{$i} {
        @extend .title;
        @extend .is-#{$i}
    }
}
```

Issues.Title: Enable using em/rem units for breakpoints (in addition to px)
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->
<!-- DO NOT REBUILD THE CSS OUTPUT IN YOUR PR -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is an **improvement**.
<!-- New feature? Update the CHANGELOG.md too, and eventually the Docs. -->
<!-- Improvement? Explain how and why. -->
<!-- Bugfix? Reference that issue as well. -->
Currently the only thing preventing usage of em/rem values for breakpoints is the hardcoded calculation of `max-width` neccessary to create the range.

### Proposed solution

<!-- Which specific problem does this PR solve and how?  -->
<!-- If it fixes a particular Issue, add "Fixes #ISSUE_NUMBER" in your title -->
This PR replaces the `$breakpoint - 1px` calculation when defining media query ranges with a function that adapts to the breakpoint unit and creates an appropriate "a bit smaller than input" value.

### Tradeoffs

<!-- What are the drawbacks of this solution? Are there alternative ones? -->
<!-- Think of performance, build time, usability, complexity, couplingâ€¦) -->
- Breakpoint mixins slightly less readable
- Possible naming conflict with a function named `calculateMqMaxWidth`. The function could be prefixed with `bulma_` to avoid that.

### Testing Done
- Tested output for breakpoints with pixel- and em-units.

Issues.Title: Change sass-cli page from gem to Dart Sass?
Issues.Body:
This is about ** the Docs**.

I went through the tutorial on this page: [https://bulma.io/documentation/customize/with-sass-cli/](https://bulma.io/documentation/customize/with-sass-cli/)

Which is fantastic that it exists, because I am not a web-dev, and I really dislike yarn and npm,
and am thrilled to avoid them both. (mostly because I don't know them well)

But, going through it, installing the gem failed, and I ended up using Dart Sass,
which is the [primary implementation of Sass](https://sass-lang.com/dart-sass)

The issues with the gem are:
- installation doesn't go smooth on some systems (at least my Ubuntu 18.04)
- Dart Sass installs simply with an unzip & add to path
- Dart Sass is the primary implementation of Sass


I propose updating  the sass-cli page to use Dart Sass

I will do it, if the maintainers express interest in having a PR submitted for this small proposal.

I would do:
- add installation directions for Dart Sass on Linux (the Dart Sass directions are a little weak for beginners)
- remove gem install directions
- fix sass arguments format for Dart Sass ( `--sourcemap=none` has changed, etc...)
- fix `@import "../node_modules/bulma/sass/utilities/_all.sass";` lines to use correct or dynamic bulma version path like earlier in page



I really am thrilled with Bulma and this cli-based sass tutorial, so I wanna give a little love back. 


Thank you
Cameron
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Change sass-cli page from gem to Dart Sass?" (#3033)

Issues.Title: Overriding the $notification-padding variable only works when also overriding the notification-padding-ltr and notification-padding-rtl variables as well
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

<!-- This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** -->
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [0.9.0]
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

It seems that adjusting the notification padding back to the default from previous versions of Bulma (I believe before 0.8.0 when all the paddings/margins changed w/ the larger form controls update) no longer works. I have customized Bulma quite a lot and have plenty of custom colors, variables and so on so I know my SASS file is working fine, but since upgrading to 0.9.0 I am unable to update the notification padding without also updating the variables for `ltr` and `rtl`. Should the ltr & rtl variables be derived perhaps? 
<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->


### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a sass file per the docs in order to customize Bulma
2. Override the `$notification-padding` variable, a la `$notification-padding: 0.375rem 0.75rem;`
3. Import Bulma as normal: `@import "~bulma/bulma";`
<!--
1. First Step
2. Second Step
3. and so on...
-->

### Expected behavior

Notification padding should be set to `0.375rem 0.75rem`
<!-- What you expected to happen -->

### Actual behavior

Notification padding remains at the default value in `~bulma/bulma/sass/elements/notification.sass`: `$notification-padding: 1.25rem 2.5rem 1.25rem 1.5rem !default`

This can be overcome by also overriding the other padding variables in this file, but this is not immediately clear to people who had adjusted it prior to the addition of the `ltr` and `rtl` variables:
```
$notification-padding: 0.375rem 0.75rem;
$notification-padding-ltr: 0.375rem 0.75rem;
$notification-padding-rtl: 0.375rem 0.75rem;
```
Perhaps it would be good to derive the `ltr` and `rtl` variables from the main one, or set a boolean to allow this just so we don't have to override all three. In writing up the details for this issue I figured out the solution, but I believe this should either be made clear or there might be an opportunity for an enhancement at least. Thanks!


<!-- What actually happened -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Overriding the $notification-padding variable only works when also overriding the notification-padding-ltr and notification-padding-rtl variables as well" (#3025)

Issues.Title: .columns exceeds width of the page in a .hero-foot and adds whitespace at bottom of page
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.0
My **browser** is: Chrome 83 (MacOS)
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

Placing a .columns element (with two columns) inside a .hero-foot element will cause the .columns element's width to exceed that of the display, which in turn causes the rest of the page to "squash", particularly on smaller devices.

### Steps to Reproduce

I've made a JSFiddle here: https://jsfiddle.net/qe4rpksw/

Although it's perhaps easier to see the problem in a full page since JSFiddle seems to have the bottom of the page cropped off for some reason, in which case one can just copy over the HTML to a local document.

### Expected behavior

The .columns element should be the same width as the rest of the page, for example the .hero-foot. There should be no whitespace underneath the .hero-foot.

### Actual behavior

The .columns element is wider than the page (it appears to be always by 24px). This also causes display issues on mobile because when the page gets shrunk down to accommodate this larger-than-the-screen element it squashes the .hero-foot element. There's also some whitespace underneath the .hero-foot.

![Screenshot 2020-06-29 at 15 51 17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52198062/86021477-05aafb00-ba21-11ea-80f5-7cb3d86a2b8b.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".columns exceeds width of the page in a .hero-foot and adds whitespace at bottom of page" (#3023)
